title: 16-E
statement: E. Fishtime limit per test3 secondsmemory limit per test128 megabytesinputstdinoutputstdoutnfish, numbered from1ton, live in a lake. Every day right one pair of fish meet, and the probability of each other pair meeting is the same. If two fish with indexes i and j meet, the first will eat up the second with the probabilityaij, and the second will eat up the first with the probabilityaji= 1 -aij. The described process goes on until there are at least two fish in the lake. For each fish find out the probability that it will survive to be the last in the lake.InputThe first line contains integern(1 ≤n≤ 18) — the amount of fish in the lake. Then there follownlines withnreal numbers each — matrixa.aij(0 ≤aij≤ 1) — the probability that fish with indexieats up fish with indexj. It's guaranteed that the main diagonal contains zeros only, and for other elements the following is true:aij= 1 -aji. All real numbers are given with not more than 6 characters after the decimal point.OutputOutputnspace-separated real numbers accurate to not less than 6 decimal places. Number with indexishould be equal to the probability that fish with indexiwill survive to be the last in the lake.ExamplesInput20 0.50.5 0Output0.500000 0.500000Input50 1 1 1 10 0 0.5 0.5 0.50 0.5 0 0.5 0.50 0.5 0.5 0 0.50 0.5 0.5 0.5 0Output1.000000 0.000000 0.000000 0.000000 0.000000

processed.result:
There are $n$ fish in a lake. Each day, a random pair of fish meet. If fish $i$ meets fish $j$, fish $i$ eats fish $j$ with probability $a_{ij}$ and fish $j$ eats fish $i$ with probability $1-a_{ij}$. This continues until there are at least two fish left in the lake. 

For each fish, find the probability that it will be the last fish remaining in the lake.

Input:

* The first line contains the number of fish, $n$.
* The next $n$ lines each contain $n$ real numbers, representing the probabilities $a_{ij}$.  The diagonal elements are all 0, and for any other element $a_{ij}$, $a_{ji} = 1 - a_{ij}$.

Output:

* Output $n$ space-separated real numbers, each representing the probability that the corresponding fish will be the last one remaining.

There are 'n' creatures. Each day, two creatures randomly meet. If they meet, the first creature eats the second with a certain probability (given in the input), and the second creature eats the first with the remaining probability. This continues until only one creature is left.  What is the probability that each creature will be the last one remaining?
